awd_titl_txt: LTREB RENEWAL: The population dynamics of forest understory invasion: mechanistic experiments with generalist herbivores, natives, and invaders
awd_abstract_narration:
Invasive species threaten the integrity of native ecosystems and cause billions of dollars in economic losses in the US annually. This long-term project will identify the mechanisms that allow some species to be invasive, and some communities to be invaded, while others are not. It is an exciting example of a public-scientist partnership in research and management, as the investigator works collaboratively with local and regional officials on the conservation of their natural areas, outreach to public visitors of these areas, and developing and assessing a virtual field trip that engages middle school students who are unable to visit the research site directly. The project will continue to provide training for undergraduate and graduate students, with a particular emphasis on recruiting students from groups under-represented in field ecology. 

This award supports Phase II of a decadal project to understand the population- and community-level dynamics of invasion by garlic mustard. The investigator will collect vital rate data on seven focal species, including three native herbaceous perennials that are highly palatable to deer, two native herbaceous perennials unpalatable to deer, a native winter annual, and the highly invasive garlic mustard. A Life Table Response Experiment will include two fully crossed treatments: plots are either open or fenced to exclude deer, and plots divided between garlic mustard presence and its removal.  Demographic matrix projection analyses and Integral Projection Models analyses will be used to project population growth rates and the long-term fates of focal species under the deer and invader scenarios generated by the experiment. Demographic analyses will be complemented by experiments exploring the hypothesized mechanisms of invasion success. Results from Phase I of this project indicated that chemicals released by garlic mustard suppress physiological function and carbon storage of the focal natives by disrupting the native plant-mycorrhizal mutualism. In Phase II, additional data on the physiological status of plants the four treatments will be compared. Instantaneous photosynthetic and transpiration rates, stomatal conductance and fluorometric measurements of focal plants will provide insights into carbon stress as a mechanism of native decline and invader domination.

por.por_cntn:
Forests in many parts of the world are negatively impacted by anthropogenic factors including non-native invasive plants and overabundant populations of native ungulate herbivores (e.g., deer, moose, elk). In North America, human introductions of invasive plant species are rapidly and profoundly changing terrestrial environments and pose a unique set of basic scientific and applied management challenges. Likewise, heavy grazing associated with locally high densities of deer negatively affects biodiversity and community dynamics of native plant communities, timber production, agricultural and fruit tree crops, home gardens and landscaping, and alters critical ecosystem processes. This project explored forest invasion by testing hypotheses of how a plant invader and overabundant deer altered native plant performance within a temperate deciduous forest understory. The main field experiment focused on responses of a set of common, long-lived, native herbaceous perennial wildflowers. Growth, survival, flowering, seed production, and seed germination data were collected annually for the focal wildflower species in large, replicate long-term field experimental plots in Pennsylvania. In these plots, the noxious plant invader (garlic mustard, Alliaria petiolata, Brassicaceae) and an overabundant mammalian herbivore (white-tailed deer, Odocoileus virginianus, Cervidae) were either present at natural densities or removed via weeding or fencing, respectively, for nearly two decades. This experimental design allowed for the analyses of data on the individual and combined effects of the invader and herbivore on the native wildflower community.

Most plants, including the native forest understory wildflowers in this study, critically rely on a mutualistic interaction with fungi that lives inside and outside plant roots. In the mutualism, the plant supplies the fungus with carbon gained by photosynthesis and the fungus provides the plant with soil nutrients and water. Garlic mustard does not form a mutualistic partnership with soil fungi. In addition, it produces an allelochemical, allyl isothiocyanate (AITC), which suppresses fungal growth in the soil. This research found that when garlic mustard is present, its AITC is detectable in the soil and the abundance of the soil fungi that are beneficial to the native wildflowers declines significantly. Loss of soil fungi results in a disruption of the nutritional mutualism between the plant and fungal partners. Analyses of focal wildflowers in the presence of garlic mustard indicated they were stressed. Specifically, the ability of the focal native understory wildflowers to maintain normal physiological functions (e.g., photosynthesis, transpiration, etc.) relative to focal plants in plots without garlic mustard was lower. As a result, over the 17-year duration of this field experiment, focal plants growing in the presence of garlic mustard exhibited declines in vegetative size, flowered less frequently, and experienced higher mortality than plants in plots where garlic mustard was removed. The AMF community in the soil diverged between the weeded and invaded treatments, which indicated long-term effects of garlic mustard on fungi. Analyses of focal wildflower population stability indicated lower demographic rates where garlic mustard is present. These novel physiological and growth results are further supported by data from a common garden experiment at the field site where 10 wildflower species were grown with or without garlic mustard. In addition, analyses of biennial census data on all 28 herbaceous species in the long-term plots revealed that those that form partnerships with AM fungi significantly declined in abundance over the duration of the experiment relative to plant species that do not form fungal partnerships. Likewise, analyses of species abundance in the forest understory community from Forest Inventory and Analysis long-term plots across the state of Illinois exhibited the same trend. Companion controlled-environment lab studies provided mechanistic explanations for the declines in individual plant size and species abundance: focal plant species in the garlic mustard treatment exhibited lower physiological rates, grew less, and stored less carbon in their rhizomes than control plants. Together these field, common garden and lab experimental results support the importance of mutualism disruption via allelochemicals as a mechanism of invader success and contribute to an understanding of species declines and biodiversity loss in invaded forests. 

Deer also significantly depressed the demographic rates of native wildflowers. Surprisingly, both wildflowers that deer browsed and those they find unpalatable exhibited negative population parameters. This occurred because deer create stressful abiotic conditions in the understory: the wildflowers experienced drier, more compacted soil, a higher proportion of bare ground, and more light reaching the soil surface in plots where deer had access. Yet these conditions that are stressful to the perennial wildflowers favor the population growth of the biennial garlic mustard, linking its invasion of forests to high browse pressure by deer. 

Synthesis: Analyses of long-term experimental plot data coupled with results from field and controlled environment experiments provided concrete mechanistic support for mutualism disruption through allelopathy, and for changes in species interactions (high deer browse pressure) in facilitating forest invasion and decreasing standing biodiversity in the forest understory.
